segment.source: 4964(S) Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.
segment.target: 4964(S) Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4964(S) Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.
segment.target: Describes security event 4964(S) Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.

segment.source: 4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.
segment.target: 4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event occurs when an account that is a member of any defined Special Group logs in.
segment.target: This event occurs when an account that is a member of any defined Special Group logs in.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Note Special Groups is a new feature in Windows Vista and in Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Note Special Groups is a new feature in Windows Vista and in Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: The Special Groups feature lets the administrator find out when a member of a certain group logs on to the computer.
segment.target: The Special Groups feature lets the administrator find out when a member of a certain group logs on to the computer.

segment.source: The Special Groups feature lets an administrator set a list of group security identifiers (SIDs) in the registry.
segment.target: The Special Groups feature lets an administrator set a list of group security identifiers (SIDs) in the registry.

segment.source: To add Special Groups perform the following actions:
segment.target: To add Special Groups perform the following actions:

segment.source: 1. Open Registry Editor.
segment.target: 1. Open Registry Editor.

segment.source: 2. Locate and then click the following registry subkey: HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetControlLsaAudit
segment.target: 2. Locate and then click the following registry subkey: HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetControlLsaAudit

segment.source: 3. On the Edit menu, point to New, and then click String Value.
segment.target: 3. On the Edit menu, point to New, and then click String Value.

segment.source: 4. Type SpecialGroups, and then press ENTER.
segment.target: 4. Type SpecialGroups, and then press ENTER.

segment.source: 5. Right-click SpecialGroups, and then click Modify.
segment.target: 5. Right-click SpecialGroups, and then click Modify.

segment.source: 6. In the Value date box, type the group SIDs, and then click OK.
segment.target: 6. In the Value date box, type the group SIDs, and then click OK.

segment.source: A semicolon character (;) can be used to delimit the SID list.
segment.target: A semicolon character (;) can be used to delimit the SID list.

segment.source: For example, you can use the following string that contains a semicolon to delimit two SIDs:
segment.target: For example, you can use the following string that contains a semicolon to delimit two SIDs:

segment.source: For more information see: http://blogs.technet.com/b/askds/archive/2008/03/11/special-groups-auditing-via-group-policy-preferences.aspx
segment.target: For more information see: http://blogs.technet.com/b/askds/archive/2008/03/11/special-groups-auditing-via-group-policy-preferences.aspx

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested logon for New Logon account.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested logon for New Logon account.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested logon for New Logon account.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested logon for New Logon account.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.
segment.target: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.

segment.source: It also can be used for correlation between a 4964 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials” and “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: It also can be used for correlation between a 4964 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials” and “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.

segment.source:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.
segment.target:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.

segment.source: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.
segment.target: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.

segment.source: New Logon:
segment.target: New Logon:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that performed the logon.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that performed the logon.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that performed the logon.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that performed the logon.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.
segment.target: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.

segment.source: It also can be used for correlation between a 4964 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials” and “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: It also can be used for correlation between a 4964 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials” and “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.

segment.source: Special Groups Assigned Type = UnicodeString: the list of special group SIDs, which New LogonSecurity ID is a member of.
segment.target: Special Groups Assigned Type = UnicodeString: the list of special group SIDs, which New LogonSecurity ID is a member of.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.
segment.target: For 4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.

segment.source: Generally speaking, every 4964 event should be monitored, because the purpose of Special Groups is to define a list of critical or important groups (Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins, service account groups, and so on) and trigger an event every time a member of these groups logs on to a computer.
segment.target: Generally speaking, every 4964 event should be monitored, because the purpose of Special Groups is to define a list of critical or important groups (Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins, service account groups, and so on) and trigger an event every time a member of these groups logs on to a computer.

segment.source: For example, you can monitor for every Domain Administrators logon to a non-administrative workstation.
segment.target: For example, you can monitor for every Domain Administrators logon to a non-administrative workstation.
